n caterpillar layers move at (n+1)/2 times the speed of a single one. This is simply because with n caterpillar layers the bottom layer moves at 1 times caterpillar speed, the second layer at 2 times caterpillar speed and so on. Assuming that each layer has the same number of caterpillars the total speed of the stack will be the average of these.
We get (1+2+...+n)/n. Since (1+2+...+n) = n*(n+1)/2 the division by n leads to (n+1)/2.

N layers of caterpillars will move (N+1)/2 times faster, in average*, compared to a single caterpillar.

The speed of the group of caterpillars compared to a single caterpillar will vary depending on how many layers/levels of caterpillars there are.

Here is the logic that I used using 3 layers: When a caterpillar is on the bottom layer, it will move at the same speed (It will remain on the first layer for 1/3rd of the time), when on the second layer, it will move 2x the speed (It will remain on the second layer for 1/3rd of the time), when on the third layer, it will move 3x the speed (It will remain on the third layer for 1/3rd of the time before it goes back to first layer again). Converting the paragraph above into math: 1*(1/3)+2*(1/3)+3*(1/3) = 2

Therefore: 3 layers of caterpillars will move 2x as fast as a single caterpillar. To find the equation for N layers, you can rewrite the equation above to: (1+2+3+...+N)/N using some algebra you can then simplify it to: (N+1)/2.

*I mentioned the words 'in average' because this formula only works for a complete cycle. Meaning that it's only true if the caterpillar rotates through all the levels. This is just one of many approaches to this problem.

Hey, no idea about the rates of speed specifically, but I might be able to explain the behaviour. First though, let's talk Ants.

Most ants have clavate antenna which are used for an ability called Tandem Running. They will head off in pairs with a follower tapping the abdomen of the leader ant. If the tapping stops, the lead ant assumes the follower is lost and will being to circle in ever expanding circles until they find them, and head off leading the tapping follower once again. The caterpillars don't seemingly have similar antennae, but as they are in constant contact with one another they are in fact using a similar touch communication that ceases when they get too far from one another, such as when the last one stops, and the one just ahead of them realizes and stops as well, sending the signal down the pack toward the head.

Caterpillars also lack the sophisticated eyes of most other insects because they are a larval form of the insect, mostly having simple Ocelli which cannot discern complex images, and are simply used to detect the presence or absence of light. Caterpillars also tend to have their heads pointed in a downward fashion, not straight ahead, as it allows for focusing on what they are feeding on below them. As such, the ocelli on those at the front of those packs of caterpillars you saw would have their Ocelli tilted forward and not picking up as much light as those caterpillars at the back of the pack, who would have them tilted upward more. The rear caterpillar likely freezes when it notices a significant change in light levels, which indicates the potential presence of a predator, in an attempt to blend in with their surroundings. This is a defensive process known as Mimesis (Insects that try to look like something else in their environment, such as like a twig, or leaf, or a shadow in this case) and possibly also Thanatosis (playing dead). When those in front notice the lack of contact/movement from those in back, the ones who can best sense if a predator is casting a shadow over them all, it's possible they stop in turn which would create that undulating motion we see generating from the rear. The rear ones wouldn't control direction, just simply control the "brakes" for the pack. Those on the bottom layer appeared lethargic compared to those on top (activity-wise, not speaking of lateral speed) which may be due to their consistently darkened Ocelli, meaning those at the very centre of the bottom layer may in fact be entirely still. As my instructor would likely be saying, this would be an interesting research paper for someone.

BTW, If you are interested in learning more about bugs and can make it out toward where you filmed your autorotation video, I can make introductions with my Entomology Professor Dr. Cameron Lait, who was called in to discern the origin of the Killer Wasp everyone was panicking (needlessly) for their lives over. He is building an impressive arthropod collection, and I know he is teaching his Apiculture course this summer, so if things go well with the restrictions I am sure he would love to show you and your son around his beehives sometime soon. Great video btw.

I'm suspicious that it is instead a sensory input control system (humans have one of these to stand upright, among many other systems).  Natural selection could reward the caterpillar pile that stays together.  I recall you noticed that the origin of the "pause" is a "sometimes" thing - sometimes from front to back, sometimes from back to front.  I would guess that if they're in the middle, they don't decide much but instead respond to a pause/start to send the signal, because if they're in the middle they're "together".  I would guess that if they're either the front or the back (as detected by having a breezy edge), they can initiate a pause/start either in response to a motor pause/start signal transmitted by a neighbor, or a detection that there's too big of a difference between the speeds of it's neighbors (felt as detecting a neighbor slide away or feeling like catching up on a neighbor).  Ends up being a PID system tuned to "stay together" with some clever targeting thoughts.  But your observation that this model is efficient definitely makes sense - they get to "share" forward travel at the comparatively low cost of bearing load!

The trick to walking on lego is to step on just one piece and it has to be in the dark.

The single blue piece had a rate of 20 spaces in 20 frames, giving it a unit rate of one space per frame.

While the grouped blue piece moved 36 spaces in 20 frames. This gives it a unit rate of 1.8 spaces per frame, so not quite double the speed but close too!

The real question is, does the rate of the speed increase or decrease as we add more layers? And is this change in rate linear or exponential?
With all layers being equal length the total speed is always v*(n+1)/2 with n as the number of layers and v as the speed of a single carterpillar.

If you compare the the group as you travel with the single carterpillar as a frame of reference, you'll see that in relation to the single carterpillar it moves forward by the speed it can propagate the group by a single carterpillar length. With one layer that's half the speed of a carterpillar, so the speed is actually 1.5 times.

In other words: With two layers of equal length, half of the objects get double the speed. 1/2 * v + 1/2 * 2v = 1.5*v
With n layers of equal length it would be:
sum with i=1 to n of 1/n * i * v, 1/n * v is constant and can be moved to the front, sum with i=1 to n of i according to the gaussian series formular equals n(n+1)/2
the total speed is therefore always v*(n+1)/2 with n as the number of layers and v as the speed of a single carterpillar

d=distance (always 1)
v=Distance/time (always 1/1)


For two layers:
average V = (2+ 1) / 2 = ***1.5 Times faster***

For more than 2 layers, it gets more complicated because all bugs travel on layer 1and then get split between layers 2 and 3, and then always go back to layer 1. Since layer 3 pulls bugs away from the back at a speed of 3 while layer 2 pulls them away at a speed of 2, the top layer will handle 3/5ths of the bugs while the second layer handles 2/5ths.

For 3 layers:
average Velocity = ([3/5]*3 + [2/5]*2 + 1) / 2 = (.6*3 + .4*2 + 1) / 2 = (1.8 + .8 + 1) / 2 = ***1.8 times faster***

Same as 3 layers, with 4 layers all bugs travel layer 1 then split between 2, 3, and 4. As a rule, 4/9ths go to layer 4, 3/9ths go to layer 3, and 2/9ths go to layer 2.

For 4 layers
Average Velocity = ([4/9]* 4 + [3/9]*3 + [2/9]*2 + 1) / 2 = 16/9 + 9/9 + 4/9 + 1 = 29/9 + 1 = ** 2.111 times faster**


Adding more layers will have diminishing returns, particularly when you start adding in time to climb up and down the layers.

So the blue block in the laminar flow analog is moving at double speed when it is in the upper layer, but when it is on the lower layer it moves at the same speed as the single block.
Meaning, the speed is not exactly doubled. My guess is 1.5x, but the count on the video doesn't match up because it is not a large enough sample size, showing mostly only the double speed portion on the top part of the helical cycle, only a couple steps at the very beginning at standard speed on the lower layer.
Thus test results are 1.9x, while more testing would probably reach the 1.5x I predict.
BTW, this type of laminar flow is what makes moving water so powerful. A small increase in depth can make a profound change in the speed of flow, but where the caterpillars move down to the bottom and slow down, the water has a relentless supply on the surface. there is usually an even more dramatic increase in part due to a reduction in helical diversion of the top layers as the water level is high enough to clear some of the substrate which causes disturbances.
As for adding a third layer, with the caterpillar example it depends on how much helical flow there is, in other words, how you cycle them through the layers.
If you have a center layer that remains fixed it is in effect the same as two layers, if you have the top two layers cycle but not interchange with the bottom layer it is the same as a single layer, if you cycle all three together in alternating entry at the rearit will not be as fast as if you cycle them in with a preference for the top layer to maintain consistent layer distribution.

I'm trying to figure it out how fast the blue lego in army is going. So here is my tought:
1) All lego has 36 points to travel.

2) Blue lonely lego travels 1 by 1 point.
It will take 36 points to finish the line.
It travelled 19 points (last photo took when army finished the line)

2) Level 1 army travels 1 by 1 point.
Level 2 army travels 1 by 1 point in the level 2, but it travels above level 1 which travels 1 point too. So, level 2 travels 2 by 2 points in ground zero.

3) Blue lego in the army travels journey points:
level 1-> 2
level 2-> 4 (in this time, blue is right above black)+ 4 (in this time, is above green) + 4 (above orange) + 4 (above white) + 1 (in the finish line)
= 19 which is right the amount of points travelled by blue alone lego

4) How fast? (by 1 move)
It depends. If blue army lego begans his journey on level 1 out of 2, it will take X points until he reachs level 2 and then, will travel 2X points.
If blue army lego starts on level 1 out of 3, it will take X points until he reachs level 2 and then, will travel 2X points until he reaches level 3 which will travel 3X points. And so on.
BUT, he cannot forgot that he does not stay in up levels forever, so he will slow down when blue lego comes down each level, travelling so many point correlated to each level.

What they are doing is creating a moving sidewalk, or "travelator". If someone walks at the same pace on as well as off, the distance covered will be the same, plus the Speed*Time=Distance of the travelator. The caterpillars below are the travelator and each successive row is additive to the one below for the time on the top row. I won't read the full 4500+ comments - but of those I did read, no one has properly described the apparent higher speed. This result only occurs if we assume that the creatures move at a constant speed, i.e: even a caterpillar with two or three layers above it still moves at "normal" speed. To do so, it would expend (arbitrarily) two or three times the energy to carry the load at normal speed. Accordingly, exerting double or triple energy in the same period of time will result in the group being able to move faster. In reality, the bottom carriers might move slower - or the group rests longer than an individual - resulting in the same average speed.

I'm just gonna do some hand-wavy argument:

On average the bug on top moves at 2x speed.

On average the bug on bottom moves at 1x speed.

If a bug spent equal amount of time on top as on bottom, on average, a bug is thus 1.5x speed.

Now. The way you had it in the lego you had 3 bugs on top and 4 on bottom, so 4/7 of the time the bug is on bottom, and 3/7 of the time it is on top, so it is 1.42x as fast.

If you had a 4 layer system with 1 bug on top, then 2, then 3, and finally 4 on bottom, you would have an average speed of 2x actually.

This is why it looks instantaneous when they change direction. When they see one of the individuals move, to them that means go that direction. I also assume this is the same for fish as they are subject to more areas of ambush than birds.

If you have n tiers, each tier travels at speed v relative to the tier below, so the absolute speed of the jth tier is jv. Averaging from 1 to n, you get (n+1)v/2. So 2 tiers is 3/2 speed of single caterpillar, 3 tiers is 2 times speed of single caterpillar, etc.

To me it is entirely different based on my knowledge of animal physiology.

Small animals have a problem of conserving heat because of their size (imagine them being small hot water bottles and bigger animals bigger bottles.) Small animals have to use most of their energy to generate heat (endotherm), however the caterpillar are mostly ectotherms (need energy from the environment) thus the caterpillars raise their temperature (if it's really cold, they can't even move) by generating and storing heat in a bigger body. This way they actually move faster because they have sufficient temperature to function.
The stopping might be, because they generate too much heat (muscle contractions generate heat) and have to stop to keep the temperature constant (simple creatures with simple explanations.) Even if faster moving might have anything to do with this, overheating is a problem.

However, they can simply avoid predators this way. As a predator you would definitely be confused if you're looking for a small worm-like creature (and you can't have any deeper thought about it.)

It almost appears similar to what starling flocks do, which is called a murmuration. Essentially each individual small animal moves in coordination with the surrounding animals in order to appear both larger than they really are as well as to create a sense of confusion for predators. No one individual caterpillar knows what the entire colony is doing but rather only a select few surrounding them, but if each caterpillar is moving in coordination with those surrounding it, and those surrounding it do the same it results in a collective actions taken by the entire colony. There is a great video on murmurations on SciShow channel, I suggest checking it out!

You said, "It's the birds or the fish in the front that dictates where the whole group goes." Its not true. Its a group behavior. +SmarterEveryDay The blue caterpillar by himself was moving about half as fast as the blue caterpillar in the group. Here is why I think so:

If we know that the average 4x2 Lego brick is about 31.8mm long, then, from adding each of the grid points, we can conclude that the length of the entire 'race-track' is 318mm. The time it took for the blue caterpillar in the group to reach the end was about 3.7s. Using the relationship v =(d/t), it can be proven that the blue caterpillar in the group was moving at about 9.0mm/s, and that the lone blue caterpillar was moving at about 49mm/s. Using the relationship t =(d/v), I determined that the lone blue caterpillar would have reached the end mark after about 6.5s. So, if I wanted to calculate what percentage faster Time 1(3.7s) of the blue caterpillar in the group is compared to Time 2(6.5s) of the lone caterpillar, I would use the formula, (T1/T2) x100, which comes out to be 57%. The blue caterpillar in the group was moving 57% faster than the lone caterpillar. This is why when the blue caterpillar in the group reached the endpoint, the lone caterpillar was only a little over halfway there.

I think this logic works...
- The caterpillars on the bottom level obviously are walking the same speed as the single caterpillar.
- The caterpillars on the second level are moving twice as fast.  On the third level are moving three times as fast.  And so on...
- Therefore, the speed that the pile of caterpillars moves as a whole will be a weighted average of the number of caterpillars on each level times and speed that level is moving.  That's another way of saying that if you were to watch a single caterpillar over a long period of time, he would on average move that fast.

In the example he showed, there were (for the most part) 4 on the bottom and three on the second row.  Therefore the speed of the group would be [(4*1) + (3*2)] / 7 = 10/7 = 1.43 times as fast as a single caterpillar.  Since the short clip he showed only has part of a whole "cycle", only showing where the blue caterpillar goes on the second row and moves twice as fast, it doesn't appear this way for the blue one, but if you look at the distance traveled by the center of the pile, it started out ahead of the single one and didn't make it to the finish line, so the relative distances traveled are in line with my calculation.

It's sort of like tank tracks.  The portion of the track that is on bottom is stationary, while the drive "wheels" are moving over the bottom portion of the track at the speed of the tank.  But then the portion of track on top is moving faster than the tank because each link at the rear moves all the way up to the front, then becomes stationary for a bit while the wheels roll over it.

Or a group of cyclists in a rotating 2-abreast pace line.  The whole pace line moves along at a certain speed, but one line is actually moving a bit faster as each person takes their turn "in the wind" at the front, and then moves over to the other line which moves a bit slower so they drop to the back, then move over again to move faster up towards the front, and so on.

So I did some math... I will try to avoid just writing formulas and also focus a bit on interpreting the results. (In case you are a nerd I also have the formulas for you and approximations, that are all accurate up to o(1)).

We will be assuming the following:
1. All caterpillars are constantly moving in their own layer with 1 caterpillarspeed
2. If a caterpillar reaches the front edge of the heap it falls down in 0 time and a carterpillar from the back gets up simultaneously in 0 time as well. (=> The number of caterpillars in one layer is constant)
3. There are n caterpillars in the ground layer (=layer number 0)
4. In layer number i over the ground there are exactly n-i caterpillars.

Here are some of my results:
The speed of a heap with k additional layers over the ground layer is (-k^2+3kn-5k+6n)/(3(2n-k)) caterpillarspeeds. Plugging in k=1, n=4, as in the lego model from the video, we get 10/7=1.4...
This is always less than (2+k)/2 but approaches this value for big n.(Except for k=0, where its value will always be 1. This of course makes sense, because there is only a ground layer travelling with the normal speed). This means, that assuming you have a very big number of caterpillars, the speed of the heap will increase by 1/2 caterpillarspeed for every added layer.
Also if you have n-1 additional layers (means the caterpillars are stacked up perfectly in a triangle) the speed will be approximately 2/3(n-1). This leads to the result that m caterpillars (in total, not just in the bottom row) can go as fast as ~2m-10sqrt(2m)/3+5. This means that the speed of the heap actually grows faster than the heap! (Mind? BLOWN!!!).
Hope you enjoyed the read. I might write a little paper about this some time :)

Ok, I did the math on the lego demonstration.
So, obviously the "lego train"' of caterpillars has an unfair advantage over the singular lego brick, as it is much longer and gets to start further ahead. The lego train is 12 studs longer than the singular brick, however it goes 4 across the finish line before it stops, so for our purposes we can say that the lego train has an 8 stud advantage over the singular brick. At the end, there is a 17 stud difference between the two racers, however because of the advantage that the lego train had, we need to subtract 8 from this number in order to get the actual amount that the single lego lost by. Subtract the two numbers from each other, and we come out to 9 studs being the actual number that the single brick lost by. The entire track is 36 studs long, from the start of the singular brick to the finish line. This means that for every 36 studs traveled, the lego train travels 9 studs faster than the single brick. 9 is one-fourth of 36, so the train is 1/4th of the way farther than the singular brick , therefore the train of legos is 1 and 1/4th times faster than than the singular lego.

The speed compounds depending on how many vertical layers there are. For example, if you walk on an escalator or airport moving walkway, your speed relative to the static ground is the sum of your speed plus the walkway's speed. Put the whole thing on a moving train and your speed is the sum of the three. Put that train on a ship and your relative speed is the sum of all the movement. Eventually, you'll be be moving as fast as Walter Payton heading for the end zone!

These are called Social Caterpillars. In a group they are actually an Army of caterpillars.
Social caterpillars are a rather rare undocumented phenomenon. Not much is known about their communication or when they move.
They are usually born into these groups, useful for finding the best leaves for the group to eat. Sometimes they can attack trees and destroy them in as little as 24 hours.
This is however not a speed advantage for the caterpillars. However, the physics demonstrated is a very interesting but precarious speed hack.

I agree with the comments of it possibly being to thwart large predators. However, I also believe this is done to conserve energy. When ducks migrate, they fly in a V formation to cut down on wind resistance. Essentially dispelling the drag and conserving energy. As for the increase in speed, this is something we humans already do with conveyor belt sidewalks at major airports. We can move at greater speeds when walking on a moving platform than when we walk alone. The caterpillar in the back controls the collective because it is essentially the last caterpillar that has not only born the most weight (it is the one on the bottom) but has also expelled the most amount of energy and still moved the slowest. So, I'd like to think, this is a form of respect for sacrificing so much for the greater good of the collective. His prize? A moment of rest before climbing up to the top and being on the other side of the collective coin. (Moving much faster while expelling a fraction of the energy).

Great video thanks. I have a couple of comments that you might find interesting. 1) The overall speed of a flock (or shoal) is determined by the flock as a whole, not by any bird 'in front'. (As far as I'm aware, you're right that a flock can't go faster than the individual birds though) 2) I think you'll find that the decision to stop and go is made by a quorum of caterpillars, rather than by any individual. You'll see several times where an individual caterpillar stops but the group keeps moving. The quorum might not be very large though, perhaps if three caterpillars stop at the same time. This is directly analogous to how our brains work.

The reason why they evolved in such a way that the last caterpillar decides when to start/stop is for a good reason. Each caterpillar might crawl with a very tiny small difference in speed. When they act as a group and crawl for a long time, the speed difference will eventually accumulate and cause the slowest caterpillar to be left behind, if there's no mechanism to "wait for it". So, if the last one in the group often (if not always) gets to decide when the group can start or stop (probably by rippling the signal through the touches), it ensures all the others in front will wait for it. Smart.

Start by simplifying the scenario by imagining the caterpillars working like a tank track, with the caterpillars on the ground stationary. From this you can figure out that since the caterpillars are only moving half of the time (when they are on the top) they should be traveling at half their normal speed. Similarly you could imagine the system as analogous to a pulley with a 2:1 mechanical advantage, also moving at 1/2 the speed of the caterpillars on top. Add in the motion of the caterpillars on the bottom and you get 1.5x the speed of a caterpillar alone. And it should simply add a factor of 1.5x speed for each additional layer.

With regards to your question if more levels will make the legos (or caterpillars) move faster: no, it wont. The speed depends on the # of legos on the bottom layer, and there only needs to be one lego on top at all times.

The reason that the group of legos moves faster than the single lego is the same reason that a wheel of larger radius will have a greater linear velocity than a wheel of smaller radius with the same angular velocity. You can treat the group of caterpillars as a wheel; a wheel made of caterpillars will move faster than a single caterpillar.

I think they travel like this because of group efficiency versus individual desire. Each individual caterpillar wants to move faster but no one member can do it on their own. If a single member ever leaves, they immediately lose the increased speed they had as a group. Since they only need two caterpillars (on a 2-D model anyways), the group isn't penalized for losing a single member. Individuals knows this though and likely only separate if the group size were too large to be beneficial.

When I attempted to do the same with "caterpillars" three or more layers high, things got really complicated really quickly. With only two layers, it is easy to figure out which caterpillars to move in order to keep going forward. When you throw up more layers, it is easy - at first - but then you quickly find caterpillars bumping into the one in front of them - because they cant move or climb fast enough to keep up. I think this is one of the reasons why they stop every now and then.

The video was going too fast for me to judge the legos so I had to try it out on excel... it appears that the top set moved at about 1.25 times the speed of the lower set, or 25% faster. When I tried the same with "legos" that were 5 blocks long, I instead got a result of 1.2 times the speed or 20% faster. This seems to hold up even if the faster set only has two caterpillars - so long as the rear caterpillar moves over the front caterpillar.

I would like to appeal to occam's razor, but any information this video gives is purely observational.

Dude! You start out the group of legos way in front of the single one. A race begins with both parties at the same point. There is a reason for that. You obfuscate, rather than illuminate. Now get your ducks (or legos) in a row.

The top tier legos actually move twice as fast as the base level. Each move forward moves them 2 notches in relationship to the one notch for the single lego opponent. When a top tier piece advances its own full length, it drops down in front of the leading base level piece, putting that row ahead by its own length. The base is stationary, but the first level, which the second level moves upon, is already moving.

The speed the aggregate blue block has over the singular blue block is 1.73x as much. 

Aggregate blue block = A
Singular blue block = S
Measuring to the forward most edge of each block:

A moved a total of 40 units (in one row) and S moved a total of 23 units (in one row).

Since both blocks are 4 units long, that means A covered it's distance in 10 block lengths and S covered it's distance in 5.75 block lengths. If you then divide A's block lengths with S's block lengths, you get 1.73.

The formula for the ratio between the speed of the entire group of caterpillars to the speed of one caterpillar is equal to (rows+1)/2.
Assuming all rows have an equal number of caterpillars, each caterpillar will also spend the same amount of time in each row. The speed of a caterpillar within the group increases linearly proportionate to the row it is on (counting up from the ground). 
Sum up the speeds (a triangular number) and divide by the rows:
[r(r+1)/2]/r
Simplified:
(r+1)/2

For the speed of the caterpillars I believe that each layer moves at different speed layer one v(1)=u, layer 2 v(2)=2u layer n v(n)=nu where u=speed of caliper. Now the total speed of the group is the number of calipers in each layer times there speeds. v= ([p(1)v(1)]+[p(2)v(2)]...+[p(n)v(n)])/n. where p(1), p(2) and p(n) are the percent of the caterpillars on each layer. Hence for 2 layers with p(1)=p(2) v=1.5u.

Each additional row contains 1 brick or caterpillar less to the previous row, its not 1/n, its x - n. Where x is the number of bricks in the bottom row. I think this leads to a divergent series. Maybe you could redo you're series using this? I would like to see what you come up with. I only did out the maths for the first row and for 1.5 times the original speed which seems to be what you got. I think the answer might be 3/2, 6/3, 10/4, 15/5
Ie the sum from 1 to n divided by n.

Speed of single brick = 1u
Speed of 2nd layer relative to ground = 2u
Speed of 3rd layer relative to ground= 3u
Distance travelled by a single brick on the second layer in a 7 brick system is 8 bricks (think about a 2 brick system).
Distance travelled on the first layer in any system by 1 brick is equal the total distance travelled in all other layers by a single brick (I think).
For a 2 layer system atleast the average speed is equal to the average speeds of the first 2 layers (1u + 2u)/2=1.5u.

The average speed of the group is equal to the average speed of an individual block (caterpillar) as it rotates through all the different positions. If there are 'n' blocks in each row (n1, n2, n3...) each moving at a velocity 'v' (v1, v2, v3...). Then the average speed is (n1*v1+n2*v2+n3*v3...)/(n1+n2+n3...). In your example, you had n1=4 blocks moving at v1=1X speed and n2 = 3 blocks moving at v2=2X speed, so the average speed is (4*1+3*2)/(3+4)=10/7 ~ 1.43X.

The first row moves at speed 1, the second at speed 2, the third at speed 3, the n-th row at speed n.

Every row contains 1/n-th part of the animals.

The total speed of a stack is the speed of each layer times the fraction that layer takes up of the total group.

This leads to: 1/n * 1 + 1/n * 2 + 1/n * 3 + ... + 1/n * n
This simplifies to: 1/n + 2/n + .. + n/n
Which is: 1 + 0.5(n-1)

speed=distance/time

comment_text:
Taking an n level lego block stack to have n blocks on the bottom level, n-1 on the second level and so to to a single block on top, I calculate the average rate of any individual block to be the base rate times (n+2)/3.

Thus for an n = 2 stack, the rate is 1.33 times as fast, for n = 3 it's 1.66 times as fast, for four it's twice as fast and so on.

You should look at the velocity of the center of mass of the caterpillars. If a single caterpillar moves at V0 m/s, then the bottom caterpillars move at V0 m/s and the top ones move at 2 * V0 m/s. This means that if there's the same number of caterpillars on the bottom as on top, the velocity of the center of mass is 1.5 * V0 m/s (use momentum). This video shows it going about twice as fast but notice that the blue caterpillar spends most of its time on top of the group, traveling at 2 * V0 m/s.

I made a fancy post explaining the speed formula in detail, but YouTube thinks my full comment is ASCII art, so I'll just state the formula. Let L be the number of layers, and S is the sum of the whole numbers through L. (e.g. L=5, S=1+2+3+4+5=15) The speed is (L+S-2)n/2(L-1).

for n layers the bottom layer is occupied half the time and the top layers in total also half the time, with equal time spent on each, so the average time taken to travel the distance of 1 layer would be the speed of all the top layers added together divided by how many top layers there are (to get the average speed of the top layers) divided by 2 (1/2 the time spent on them), plus the speed of the bottom layer divided by 2 (1.2 the time spent on the bottom layer).

15% on 2 and 25% on 3. also on layer 2 the move twice as fast, on layer 3 3 times as fast so their speed would on average be 1n,2n,1n,3n (where n is a unit of speed) so in total a speed of 7n, where a lone caterpillar would be going 1n,1n,1n,1n for a total speed of 4n so a group with 3 layers travels 7/4s or 1.75 the speed of a lone caterpillar and the ration of 1 layer to 2 layers to 3 layers (in speed) is 1:1.5:1.75

With 3 layers if they say start on layer 1, at the end of layer one they will either go to layer 2 or 3 (about 50/50 of each - on average) and at the end of either layer 2 or 3 they must travel along layer 1 to get to a higher layer next, so the patter will be layer 1 then 2 or 3 and then 1 and then 2 or 3, with both 2 and 3 being equal chance (equal number of caterpillars on both layers on average it will go 1,2,1,3, with 50% of the time spent on layer 1 (for why 50% look at previous comment),

when the caterpillars are on the bottom they move the normal speed, but when they are on top they move twice as fast, and the length on the bottom was the same as the top (even though there were just 3 on top and 4 on the bottom, because the length that they walk on on the second layer is the length of the first layer and therefore also the length on the bottom) so half the time they move twice as fast and half the time they walk at a normal speed so they walk 1.5 times as fast as normal.

I believe that a simplified version for the maths behind this is more or less like this:
In your example, 3 out of 7 caterpillars (the 3 on the top layer) give double steps for each unit of time (=one step on their own + one step given by the lower layer).  Therefore, the single caterpillar will craw 3/7 (the ratio between the top and the bottom layer) slower  than the group.

Yes, you're right. When you move one lego down and one lego up one layer, because of the 4-3 arrangement, the net total horizontal movement of those two pieces from swapping layers is 4 forward. This means that in that frame, you get not 10 total forward movement, but 14. If you want to not move pieces forward or backward when they change layer, you will half the time have four in the lower row (43% faster with my method) and half the time three in the bottom row (57% faster).

the caterpillar in the group moves in a cycle. It spends half of the cycle in the second layer, where it moves twice as fast as the individual caterpillar (relative to the track). The other half is spent in the first layer where it moves at the same speed as the individual. Thus, the average velocity of the caterpillar in the group over a whole cycle is (1/2)2v+(1/2)v=(1/2)3v=1.5v, where v is the velocity of the individual caterpillar.

Dear Destin,
Here is a careful calculation. I compare the distances earlier than the final frame-- when the compound caterpillar is in the same state as it started (upper level two clicks from lower level). The lone caterpillar has moved 8, the compound 12 for a 1.5 speedup (precisely).
Here's the explanation: level n moves n times the speed of a single guy. Clearly the cluster moves as fast as the average: doing the math gives an (n+1)/2 times speedup for n levels.

Now if we look at a model with N layers and assume that every layer is the same size and that the caterpillar spends the same time in the layers above the first and N times as much in the first (every time the caterpillar comes down) than the average speed will be:

Vn = (N*V+1*V+2*V+3*V+...+N*V)/N = V*(1+2+3+...+N+N)/N = V*(N*(N-1)/2+N)N = V*N(1+(N-1)/2)/N = V*(2+N-1)/2 = V*(N+1)/2.

The only reason the group moves faster is because the last lego/caterpillar must accelerate to mount the group, the hind legs must move twice as fast during mounting.  Since each lego is 4 in length by the time the third one is about to mount (but hasnt started) the difference is 8 pins (difference from back to back).  So the group is only moving faster because it is actually spending more energy to do so.  This is probably not the benefit (probably is mimicry/camouflage).

If V is the speed of every caterpillar, than when a caterpillar is on the bottom layer he will move at 1V and when he is on the second layer he will move at 2V.
So if there are only 2 levels and they the same size he will be spending the same time on both layer so his average speed will be 1.5V. And because this is true for every caterpillar in the group, the whole group will move at that speed.

As for the math, I'd say that the simple way of calculating things is simply to look at the legos and consider that as all of the bottom pieces move one tick, so will the ones on top. Then the top ones move their one tick each. In the example of 4-3 pieces this adds up to a total of ten sevenths (~43% increased velocity). This, of course, does not account for the factor of caterpillars transitioning between layers.

relative velocity. two layers are moving at the same speed as the blue brick on the other side. Because the first layer is moving, the second layer is moving twice as fast as the blue brick relative to the ground but moving at the same rate relative to the first layer. The difference between a sole caterpillar (c. for short) and the 2-layer c. group can only be calculated if there is a difference in speed between the bottom group and the last caterpillar to allow c. to get on top:
1. the bottom c. slows down to allow last c. to crawl on top (1<n<1,5)
2. the last and the front c. speed up to get on top and off the front 
(1,5<n<2)
Assuming they get instanty on & off: while sole c. covers it's own 2 body lengths, a 2 layer group will cover 2+1 bodylengths (1,5)

So I've done a little research on social aggregates of caterpillars. They make all kinds of fantastic formations that seem to help with growth and thermoregulation. Lets say the speed of a single caterpillar is x. In case of 2 layers, a single caterpillar is obviously in the bottom layer half of time. So he moves at the speed of x in the bottom layer and 2x (relative to the ground) in the top layer. This makes his average speed 1.5x. (relative to the ground again). When trere is the same number of caterpillars in each layer the average speed of one caterpillar and therefore the group is (x+2x+3x+4x+5x+...+nx)/n=[n(x+nx)/2]/n=(x+nx)/2.

If it costs 1 unit to move forward 1 nob carrying your own weight, then it costs 1 units to move forward 1 nob carrying twice your weight. On the top layer it still costs you 1 unit to move forward yourself forward 1 nob, but you gain the extra 1 nob movement for being on the 2nd layer. Assuming two layers of equal length (2nd may be 1 creature-length shorter), so equal time on top and bottom, then the median energy cost is 3 units energy per 2 nobs forward motion.

Imo, the concept is about relative velocity... It's like walking normally compared to walking on a conveyor belt, which adds to the velocity of a certain direction, thereby faster.. However, with more layers, the overall velocity of the object in that certain direction (say forward) Decreases, as it also has another velocity (say upwards) to move to, thus Decreasing the Resultant Velocity in a certain direction.. As the layers does not carry "Power" (like in gears), more layers = less efficiency

This is probably the same mechanic on how bait fish in the ocean swim together in large clusters, at a distance, it's much easier to confuse them as a much bigger organism, so some predators won't bother trying to prey on them because it's just too big for them

Assuming the numbers of layers and the length of the structure stays the same, you can imagine the mass distributed in layers moving at different speeds and distributed again on all layers at the front, so you can just take the average of the speeds.
Examples: Speed for 2 layers: (1+2)/2=1.5; for 3 layers: (1+2+3)/3=2; for 4 layers: (1+2+3+4)/4=2.5; for 5 layers: (1+2+3+4+5)/5=3 etc.

Second layer moves at twice the speed, third layer moves at three times the speed relative to the ground etc.
At the front every length unit of caterpillar above layer 1 gets distributed to all the layers below.
